citation.article-title: Comparative studies on [Pasteurella] testudinis and [P.] testudinis-like bacteria and proposal of Chelonobacter oris gen. nov., sp. nov. as a new member of the family Pasteurellacea
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Chelonobacter (Che.lo.no.bac′ter. Gr. n. chelone -es a tortoise; N.L. masc. n. bacter a rod; N.L. masc. n. Chelonobacter rod isolated from tortoise).

Members of the genus stain Gram-negatively and are non-motile, pleomorphic rods that are catalase- and oxidase-positive and produce acid fermentatively from glucose without gas in Hugh and Leifson's medium.
After 24 h aerobic incubation at 37 °C, regular, slightly raised, circular colonies are formed with an entire margin surrounded by a zone of β-haemolysis.
Positive for nitrate reduction and acid production from (+)-l-arabinose, dulcitol, (−)-d-mannitol, (−)-d-fructose, (+)-d-glucose, (+)-d-mannose, cellobiose, maltose, sucrose, trehalose and salicin.

Negative for X- and V-factor requirement, urease, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase, pigment formation, α-fucosidase, α-galactosidase, α-glucosidase (PNPG), β-glucuronidase (PGUA), α-mannosidase and β-xylosidase (ONPX).
Strains have been isolated from diseased tortoises and turtles.
The type species is Chelonobacter oris sp. nov.
